document_title: Autoimmune hepatitis: Causes, signs, diagnosis and prevention
subsection_content:
Autoimmune hepatitis, also known as AIH (Autoimmune Hepatitis). This is an autoimmune disorder that occurs when the body's immune system attacks liver cells, causing inflammation and damage to the liver.(1)
Autoimmune hepatitis can occur at any age, and tends to affect women more than men – it is four times more common in women than in men. People with a family history of autoimmune hepatitis are also at higher risk.
This is a type of chronic hepatitis and requires lifelong monitoring; Although there is no cure, there are many methods to help patients control symptoms and prevent the development of liver damage.
If you have autoimmune hepatitis, you are also at risk of having one or more other autoimmune diseases such as thyroid, rheumatoid arthritis, ulcerative colitis, type 1 diabetes or Sjogren's syndrome (also known as autoimmune hepatitis). Sjogren's autoimmune disorder – an autoimmune disorder involving the body's exocrine glands)
